verses.text: In the land named Uz, there was a man named Job. He obeyed God and always avoided doing evil things.
He had seven sons and three daughters.
He owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, one thousand oxen, and five hundred donkeys. He also had many servants. He was the richest man in all the area east of the Jordan River.
Job's sons often held feasts in their houses. Whenever each one made a feast, he would invite all his brothers and sisters to come and eat together.

After each celebration, Job would summon them and he would ask Yahweh to purify them from any sins or shortcomings they may have. He would get up early in the morning, kill animals, and burn them on the altar as sacrifices, one for each of his children. For Job always said, "Perhaps my children have sinned and said something evil about God in their hearts."
One day, the angels came and gathered together in front of Yahweh, and Satan came, too.

Yahweh asked Satan, "Where have you just come from?"
 Satan replied, "I have come from the earth, where I been traveling back and forth to see what is happening."
Yahweh said to Satan, "Have you noticed Job, who worships me? No one else on earth honors me and lives in such a right way as he does. He always refuses to do anything evil."
Satan replied to Yahweh, "What you say is true, but Job honors you only because of what you have done for him.
You have always protected him, his family, and everything he owns. You make him succeed in whatever work he tries to do, and he has very much livestock all over his land.
But if you attacked what he owns and took it away, he would curse you in front of everyone."

Yahweh replied to Satan, "So this is what you want me to do! All right, I will permit you to take away everything that he has. But do not harm him in his own body."
 Satan agreed and then left Yahweh in order to plan how he would attack Job.
One day after that, Job's sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the home of their oldest brother.
While they were doing that, a messenger arrived at Job's home and said to him, "While your oxen were plowing the fields and the donkeys were grazing nearby,

a group of men from the people group of Sheba came and attacked us. They killed all your servants who were working in the fields and took away all the oxen and donkeys! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."

While he was still talking to Job, another messenger arrived. He said to Job, "Lightning from the sky struck and killed all the sheep and all the men who were taking care of them! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."

While he was still talking to Job, a third messenger arrived. He said to Job, "Three groups of robbers from the region of Chaldea came and attacked us. They stole all the camels and killed all the men who were taking care of them. I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."
While he was still talking to Job, a fourth messenger arrived. He said to Job: "Your sons and daughters were feasting in the home of their oldest brother.

Suddenly a very strong wind came from the desert and struck the house. The house collapsed on your sons and daughters and killed them all! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."
Then Job stood up and tore his robe and shaved his head because he was very sad. Then he laid down on the ground to worship God.

He said,
\q1 "When I was born, I had no clothes.
\q1 When I die, I will not take any clothes with me.
\q1 Yahweh gave me everything that I possessed,
\q1 and now he has taken it all away.
\q1 But we should always praise Yahweh!"
So in spite of all the things that happened to Job, he did speak not like a foolish manâ€”he did not sin by saying that what God had done was wrong.*
On another day, the angels came again and gathered together in front of Yahweh; Satan also came again.
Yahweh asked Satan, "Where have you come from this time?" Satan replied, "I have come from the earth, where I have been traveling back and forth to see what is happening."

Yahweh asked Satan, "You have you noticed my servant Job, who worships me, have you not?
 He continues to honor me; he is very exceptional, for he lives in a way that is more right than anyone else on the earth. He does this even though you persuaded me to attack him for no reason."
Satan replied to Yahweh, "He praises you only because you have helped him. People will give up everything they have to save their own lives.
But if you harm his body, he will surely curse you in front of everyone!"
Yahweh replied to Satan, "All right, you may do to him whatever you like, but do not cause him to die."
So Satan left, and he caused Job to suffer with very painful boils, from the top of his head to the bottom of his feet.
Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped the boils on his skin, and he sat in ashes to mourn and wail.
His wife said to him, "Are you still trying to be loyal to God? You should curse God, and then go ahead and die."

But Job replied, "You talk like people talk who do not know God. We should not only accept the good things that God does for us. We should also accept the bad things." So in spite of all these things that happened to Job, he did not offend God by saying anything against him.

Among Job's friends were Eliphaz from the town of Teman, Bildad from the land of Shuah, and Zophar from the land of Naamah. When they heard about all the terrible things that had happened to Job, they left their homes and went together to Job to mourn with him and to comfort him.

But when they saw Job from a distance, they almost did not recognize him. They wailed loudly, they tore their robes, and they threw dust into the air that settled on their heads. They did this to show how sorry they were for him.

Then they sat on the ground with Job for seven days. None of them said anything to him, because they saw that he was suffering greatly, and they did not think that anything that they could say would lessen his pain.
Finally, Job spoke, and he cursed the day that he was born.

He said,
\q1

"I wish that the day when I was born could be eradicated,
\q2 the night when I was born.
\q1

I wish that the day when I was born could have been dark.
\q2 I wish that God who is in heaven would forget about that day,
\q2 and that the sun would not have shone on it.
\q1

I wish that thick darkness would have filled that day,
\q1 and that a black cloud would have come over it
\q2 and blotted out all light,
\q2 and caused the people then to be terrified.
\q1

I wish that the night when I was born would be erased from the calendar,
\q2 that it would never again appear as one night in any month,
\q2 and that it would not be included in any calendar.
\q1

I wish that no child would again be born on that date,
\q2 and that no one would again be happy then.
\q1

The people who are able to awaken the great sea monsterâ€”I want them to curse the day I was born.
\q1

I wish that the stars that shone early in the morning on that day after I was born may not shine again.
\q2 If only those stars had wished in vain for light to shi ne;
\q2 and that they had not shone on that day.
\q1

That was an evil day because my mother's womb was not closed;
\q2 instead, I was born, and I have now experienced all these terrible things.
\b
\q1

I wish that my mother had never welcomed me.
\q2 I wish that she had not nursed me at her breasts.
\q1

If I had died at the time when I was born,
\q2 I would now be asleep, resting peacefully.
\q1

I would be resting with kings who built beautiful tombs which are now in ruins,
\q2 and I would be resting with their officials who have also died.
\q1

I would be resting with princes who were wealthy,
\q2 whose palaces were filled with gold and silver.
\q1

I wish that I had been buried like a child who had died in its mother's womb
\q2 and never lived to see the light.
\q1

Rich people and poor people are alike after they die,
\q2 and those who were slaves no longer have to obey their masters.
\b
\q1

Why does God allow those who are suffering greatly like me to continue to remain alive?
\q2 Why does he allow them to live, those who are very miserable?
\q1

They long to die, but they do not die.
\q2 They desire to die more than people desire to find hidden treasure.
\q1

When they finally die and are buried, they are very happy.
\q1

I do not understand why God keeps alive anyone whom he keeps from being happy,
\q2 anyone whom he forces to live in misery.
\q1

Then Eliphaz replied to Job. He said,
\q1

"Will you please allow me to say something to you?
\q2 I am not able to remain silent any longer.
\q1

In the past, you have instructed many people,
\q2 and you have encouraged those for whom it was difficult to trust in God.
\q1

But now, when you yourself suffer from disasters, you become discouraged.
\q2 The disasters hit you, and you are stunned.
\q1

You say that you honor God; so you should be trusting in him, for him not to let you suffer.
\q2 If you really had not sinned, you would have been confident that God would not let these disasters happen to you!
\b
\q1

Think about this: No innocent people ever die when they are still young!
\q2 God never kills innocent people!
\q1

These people die when God commands them to,
\q2 because he is very angry with them.
\q1

Even though wicked people may be very powerful like young lions,
\q2 God destroys them.
\q1

They will die like older lions that starve to death when there are no animals left to eat.
\q2 Their children will scatter from each other like young lions that separate from each other to find food.
\q1

I heard a message that someone came
\q2 and whispered to me.
\q1

He spoke to me at night when I was having a bad dream that disturbed me.
\q1

A ghost glided past my face
\q2 and caused the hair on the back of my neck to stand straight up.
\q1

It stopped, but I could not see what it really looked like.
\q2 But I knew that there was some being in front of me,
\q1 and it said in a quiet voice,
\q1

'No human being can be more righteous than God.
\q1 No man can be better than God, who made him.
\q1

So he certainly cannot trust human beings whom he has made from dust and clay,
\q2 human beings, whom disaster crushes as easily as you can crush a moth!
\q1

People are sometimes in good health in the morning, but by the evening they are dead.
\q2 They are gone forever and no one even pays attention.
\q1

They are like tents that collapse suddenly when you pull up their stakes;
\q2 they die suddenly without ever knowing why.'"

"Job, no one will stop you from calling out for someone to help you,
\q2 but I am certain that no angel will come to you!
\q1

I have seen foolish people who seemed to be successful,
\q2 but suddenly they experienced disaster because I cursed their home.
\q1

Their sons are never safe;
\q2 they always lose to their opponents in court,
\q2 because there is no one to defend them.
\q1

Hungry people steal the crops that foolish people harvest;
\q2 they even steal the crops that grow among thorns,
\q2 and greedy people take away the wealth of those foolish people.
\q1

People make trouble for themselves from the time that they are born;
\q2 this is as certain as the fact that sparks shoot up from a fire.
\b
\q1

If I were suffering like you are, I would ask God for help
\q2 and tell him what I am complaining about.
\q1

He defends those who are humble,
\q2 and puts those who mourn into places where they are safe.
\q1

He causes crafty people to not be able to do what they plan to do,
\q2 with the result that they achieve nothing.
\q1

It is as though even in the daytime they were living in darkness
\q2 and were groping around trying to find the road at noontime like people do at night.
\q1

So poor people confidently expect that good things will happen to them;
\q2 but God stops wicked people from saying evil things.
\b
\q1

He will rescue you many times from your troubles,
\q2 with the result that nothing evil will happen to you.
\q1

When there is little food to eat, he will not allow you to die,
\q2 and when there is a war, your enemies will not kill you.
\q1

You will be able to laugh when that happens and when there is nothing to eat,
\q2 and you will not be afraid of wild animals.
\q1

You will not worry about having big rocks in your fields that will make plowing difficult,
\q2 and you will not worry that wild animals might attack you.
\q1

You will be certain that you will have many descendants,
\q2 who will be as numerous as blades of grass.
\q1

You will become very old before you die,
\q2 like sheaves of grain continue to grow until it is time to harvest and thresh them.
\b
\q1

My friends and I have thought carefully about these things, and we know that they are true,
\q2 so pay attention to what I have said!"

Then Job spoke again to Eliphaz:
\q1

"If all my troubles and misery could be put on a scale and weighed,
\q1

they would be heavier than all the sand along the ocean shores.
\q2 That is why I spoke very rashly about the day that I was born.
\q1

It is as though Almighty God has shot me with arrows.
\q2 It is as though those arrows have poison on their tips, and that poison has gone into my spirit.
\q1 The things that God has done to me are like soldiers lined up to attack me.
\q1

Just like a wild donkey does not complain by braying when it has plenty of grass to eat,
\q2 and an ox does not complain by bellowing when it has food to eat,
\q1 I would not complain if you were really helping me.
\q1

People complain when they must eat food that has no salt
\q2 or food that is slimy and tasteless;
\q1 that is what your words are like, Eliphaz.
\q1

I do not want to eat food like that,
\q2 because it disgusts me,
\q1 and I do not like what you have said to me.
\b
\q1

I wish that God would do for me what I have asked of him:
\q1

I wish that he would crush me and let me die.
\q2 I wish that he would reach out his hand and take away my life.
\q1

If he would do that, I would be comforted because I would know that in spite of the great pain that I have suffered,
\q2 I have always obeyed what God, the Holy One, has commanded.
\b
\q1

But now I do not have enough strength to endure all these things.
\q2 And since I have nothing to hope for in the future,
\q2 it is difficult for me to be patient now.
\q1

I am not strong like rocks are,
\q2 and my body is not made of bronze.
\q1

So I am not able to help myself;
\q2 I am not wise enough for that.
\b
\q1

When a man has many troubles, his friends should be kind to him,
\q2 even if he stops honoring Almighty God.
\q1

But you, my friends, are not dependable.
\q2 You are like streams in the wilderness: They spill over their banks in the spring
\q1

when the melting ice and snow make them overflow,
\q1

but when the dry season comes, there is no water flowing in those streams,
\q2 and the channels dry up.
\q1

The caravans of merchants turn off their road to search for water,
\q2 but there is no water in those streambeds,
\q2 so the merchants die in the desert.
\q1

The men in those caravans searched for some water
\q2 because they were sure that they would find some.
\q1

But they did not find any,
\q2 so they were very disappointed.
\q1

Similarly, you friends have not helped me at all!
\q1 You have seen that terrible things have happened to me,
\q2 and you are afraid that God might do similar things to you.
\q1

After I lost all my wealth, I did not ask any of you for money.
\q2 I did not plead with any of you to spend some of your money to help me.
\q1

I never asked any of you to rescue me from my enemies,
\q2 and I did not ask you to save me from those who oppressed me.
\q1

When people speak what is true, that truth will not hurt the person who hears it,
\q2 but what you have criticized me for having done is not true, so you have proven nothing when you say those things.
\q1

I am a man who has nothing to hope for,
\q2 but you try to correct me, and you think what I say is as useless as the wind!
\q1

You do not sympathize with me at all for the things 
that I am suffering.
\q2 You will do anything to get something for yourselves! You would even play a game to see who gets an orphan as a prize!
\b
\q1

Please look at me! I will not lie while I am talking straight to you.
\q1

Stop saying that I have sinned, and stop criticizing me unjustly!
\q2 You should realize that I have not done things that are wrong.
\q1

Do you think that I am lying?
\q2 No, I am not lying, because I know what is right to say, and what is wrong."

We are like slaves who keep wanting to be in the cool of evening,
\q2 and we are like workers who keep waiting to be paid.
\q1

When I lie down at night I say, 'How long will it be until I get up?'
\q2 But the nights are long, and I toss on my bed until the dawn.
\q1

My body is covered with maggots and scabs;
\q2 pus oozes out of my open sores.
\b
\q1

God, you see me now,
\q2 but some day you will not see me anymore.
\q2 You will search for me, but I will be gone because I will be dead.
\q1

they never return to their houses,
\q2 and the people who are still alive do not remember them anymore.
\b
\q1

God, why do you watch closely what I am doing?
\q2 Do you think that I am a dangerous sea monster?
\q1

these things make me wish that someone would strangle me to death,
\q2 rather than for me to continue to be alive when I am only a bunch of bones.
\q1

I detest continuing to be alive; I do not want to live for many more years.
\q2 Allow me to be alone, because I will be alive for only a very short time.
\b
\q1

You look at us every morning to see what we are doing,
\q2 and you 
examine us every moment to see if we are doing what is right.
\q1

When will you stop looking at me and leave me alone for a little time, long enough to swallow my own spit?
\q1

Why do you watch me constantly?
\q2 If I sin, that certainly does not harm you!
\q1 Why have you set me up like a target to shoot at?
\q2 Do you consider me to be a heavy load that you are forced to carry?
\q1

If I have sinned, are you not able to forgive me
\q2 for the wrong things that I have done?
\q1 Soon I will lie in my grave;
\q2 you will search for me, but you will not find me because I will be dead and gone."

Then Bildad, from the Shuah area, spoke to Job. He said,
\q1

"Job, how much longer will you talk like this?
\q2 What you say is as useless as a big wind.
\q1

Almighty God certainly never does anything unfairly.
\q2 He always does what is right.
\q1

But now, if only you will earnestly request Almighty God to help you!
\q1

If only you were pure and honest!
\q2 Then he will surely do something good for you
\q2 and reward you by giving your family back to you and making you prosper.
\q1

Even though you were not very prosperous before,
\q2 during the last stage of your life you would become very wealthy.
\b
\q1

I request you to think about what happened long ago
\q2 and to consider what our ancestors found out.
\q1

It seems as though we were born only yesterday
\q2 and we know very little;
\q1 our time here on the earth disappears quickly, like a shadow that is here and then gone.
\q1

So why not allow your ancestors to teach you anything?
\q2 Let them tell you what they learned!
\q1

If the water dries up while they are blossoming,
\q2 they wither more quickly than any other plant.
\q1

Godless people are like plants that are watered before the sun rises:
\q2 their shoots spread all over the gardens.
\q1

The roots of those plants twist around the piles of stones
\q2 and cling tightly to the rocks.
\q1

But if a gardener pulls those plants out,
\q2 it is as though the place where they were planted says, 'They were never here!'
\q2 That is what happens to wicked people who do not pay attention to what God says.
\q1

Truly, this is all the joy that evil people have:
\q2 other people just come and take their places.
\b
\q1

So, I tell you, Job, God will not reject you if you honor him,
\q2 but he does not help evil people.
\q1

He will always enable you to laugh
\q2 and to 
shout joyfully.
\q1

But those who hate you will be very ashamed,
\q2 and the homes of wicked people will disappear."

Then Job replied,
\q1

"Yes, yes, I know.
\q2 But how can anyone say to God, 'I am innocent'?
\q1

If someone wanted to argue with God about that,
\q2 God could ask him a thousand questions
\q2 and that person would not be able to answer any of them!
\q1

He even moves mountains in earthquakes without telling anyone in advance.
\q2 When he is angry, he turns the mountains upside down.
\q1

Some days he speaks to the sun, and it does not rise,
\q2 and some nights he prevents the stars from shining.
\q1

He set in their places the groups of starsâ€” the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades, and the groups of stars in the southern sky.
\q1

God will not very easily stop being angry;
\q2 he defeated the servants of Rahab, the great sea monster.
\b
\q1

If God took me to court,
\q2 what could I say to answer him?
\q1

Even though I would be innocent, I would not be able to answer him.
\q2 All I could do would be to request God, my judge, to act mercifully toward me.
\q1

If I summoned him to come to the courtroom and he said that he would come,
\q2 I would not believe that he would pay attention to what I would say.
\q1

He sends storms to batter me,
\q2 and he bruises me many times without any reason.
\q1

It is as though he will not let me get my breath
\q2 because he causes me to suffer all the time.
\q1

If I tried to wrestle with him, there would be no way to defeat him,
\q2 because he is stronger than I am.
\q1 If I called him to appear in court,
\q2 there is no one who could force him to go there.
\q1

Even though I was innocent, anything I said would cause him to punish me;
\q2 even though I had not done anything wrong, he would still prove that I was guilty.
\b
\q1

I have not done anything wrong, but that is not important anymore because I do not care what happens to me.
\q2 I despise living.
\q1

Nothing is important to me
\q2 because God will get rid of all of us, both those who are innocent and those who are wicked.
\q1

When people experience disaster and it causes them to suddenly die,
\q2 God laughs at it, even if they are innocent.
\q1

God has allowed wicked people to control what happens in the world.
\q2 It is as though he had caused judges to be blind, no longer able to judge fairly.
\q1 If it is not God who has done that,
\q2 who, then, has done it?
\b
\q1

My life goes by very rapidly, like a swiftly sailing boat made from reeds
\q2 or like an eagle that swoops down to seize an animal.
\q1

then I become afraid because of all that I am suffering
\q2 because I know that God does not consider that I am innocent.
\q1

He will condemn me anyway,
\q2 so why should I keep trying in vain to defend myself?
\q1

If I washed myself with snow
\q2 or cleansed my hands with lye
\q2 to get rid of my guilt,
\q1

he would still throw me into a filthy pit;
\q2 as a result it would be as though even my clothes would detest me.
\b
\q1

God is not a human, as I am,
\q2 so there is no way that I could answer him to prove that I am innocent
\q2 if we went together to have a trial in a courtroom.
\q1

There is no one to mediate,
\q2 no one who has authority over both of us.
\q1

I wish someone else could stop God from making me suffer,
\q2 and that he would not continue to terrify me.
\q1

If he did that, I would declare that I am innocent without being afraid of him
\q2 because I know within myself that I really have not done what is wrong like God thinks that I have.

I detest living any longer.
\q1 I will not stop saying why I am complaining.
\q2 Since I am very unhappy, I will speak.
\q1

Does it please you to oppress me,
\q2 to abandon me, whom you created,
\q2 and, at the same time, to help wicked people to do the things that they plan to do?
\q1

Do you understand things the way that we humans do?
\q1

Do you live for only a few years, like [as] we do?
\q1

So why do you continue to search for my faults
\q2 and to hunt for my sins?
\q1

You know that I am not guilty,
\q2 and that no one can rescue me from your power.
\b
\q1

With your hands you created me and shaped my body,
\q2 but now you are deciding that you should not have done that, and you are destroying me instead.
\q1

You certainly formed me when I was conceived,
\q2 and you put me together inside my mother's womb.
\q1

You fastened my bones together with sinews,
\q2 and then you covered them with flesh inside my skin.
\q1

You have caused me to be alive; you have faithfully loved me,
\q2 and you have carefully preserved me.
\b
\q1

You were watching to see if I would sin,
\q2 so that, if I did sin, you would refuse to forgive me.
\q1

If I am a wicked man, I hope that terrible things will happen to me.
\q1 But even if I am righteous, I still must bow my head and feel ashamed
\q2 because I am very disgraced and feel miserable.
\q1

And if I am proud, you hunt me like a lion hunts for some animal to kill,
\q2 and you act powerfully to injure me.
\q1

You constantly find more witnesses to testify that I have done what is wrong,
\q2 and you continually become more angry with me.
\q2 It is as though you are [were] always bringing new troops to attack me.
\b
\q1

God, why did you allow me to be born?
\q2 I wish had died when I was born, and that no one had ever seen me.
\q1

I think it would have been better if I had been carried directly from my mother's womb to the grave
\q2 than for me to live.
\q1

before I go to the place from which I will never return,
\q2 [a place] where it is always gloomy and very dark,
\q1

a place of darkness and dark shadows where everything is confused
\q2 [and] where even the small light there is like darkness.'"

Then Zophar, the friend from the region of Naamah, said this to Job:
\q1

"Should no one answer all that you have said?
\q2 Just because you talk a lot, that fact should not persuade us to declare that you are innocent.
\q1

Job, should your babbling really cause us to be silent?
\q2 When you make fun of what we think, certainly there should be someone to rebuke you and cause you to be ashamed!
\q1

But I wish that God would talk
\q2 and say something to answer you!
\q1

God knows everything about everything,
\q2 so I wish that he would tell you the secrets that he knows because he is wise.
\q1 It would be good if you realized that God is punishing you less than you deserve!
\b
\q1

Tell me, will you ever be able to find out the things about God that are very difficult to understand?
\q2 Will you be able to find out everything that there is to know about Almighty God?
\q1

What there is to know about God is wider than the earth
\q2 and wider than the ocean.
\b
\q1

If God comes to you and puts you in prison and then brings you to a trial,
\q2 who can stop him?
\q1

Stupid people like you will start to become wise 
\q2 when wild donkeys start giving birth to people.
\b
\q1

You will lie down to sleep, and no one will make you afraid.
\q2 And many people will come and request you to be kind to them.
\q1

Then Job said to his three friends,
\q1

"There is no doubt that you are the people to whom everyone should listen,
\q2 and that when you die, there will be no more wise people alive.
\q1

But I have as much good sense as you do;

Then Eliphaz replied, saying this:
\q1

\q1

"It is true that there are places where men dig to find silver,
\q2 and there are places where people refine gold that they have dug.

\q1

\q1

Some birds have very good eyes,
\q1 but even hawks do not know where the mines are,
\q2 and falcons have not seen those places.
\q1

Lions or other proud wild animals have never gone to those places.
\q1

They cut tunnels through the rocks,
\q2 and they find precious things.
\q1

They dam up small streams to stop the water from flowing,
\q2 and they bring up into the light things that are hidden in the ground and in the streams.
\b
\q1

But wisdom: Where can people find that?
\q2 Where can we find out how to truly understand things?
\q1

It is as though the water that is under the earth and water that is in the seas said,
\q2 'I do not have it!'
\q1

People cannot buy wisdom
\q2 by paying for it with silver or gold.
\q1

Wisdom is worth much more than fine gold from the land of Ophir,
\q2 much more than very valuable stones.
\q1

It is worth much more than gold or beautiful quartz,
\q2 worth more than vases made from fine gold.
\q1

The prices of topaz from Ethiopia and of pure gold
\q2 are lower than the value of wisdom.
\b
\q1

\q2 Where can we find out how to truly understand things?
\q1

It is as though the places where people go after they die said,
\q2 'We have only heard rumors about where to find wisdom.'
\q1

He decided how strongly the winds should blow,
\q2 and how much rain should be in the clouds,
\q1

\q2 and what path lightning should take from the clouds down to the ground.
\q1

At that time he saw wisdom and decided that it is very valuable.
\q2 He examined it and approved it.
\q1

And then he said to human beings, 'Listen! If you have much respect for me, you will be able to become wise;
\q2 to truly understand everything, you must first turn away from doing what is evil.'"

Job spoke again and said this:
\q1

"I wish that I could be as I was previously
\q2 during the years when God took care of me.
\q1

During those years, it was as though God's lamp shone on me
\q2 and gave me light while I walked in the darkness.
\q1

At that time I was young and strong,
\q2 and because God was my friend, he protected where I lived.
\q1

Almighty God was with me during those years
\q2 when all my children were around me.
\q1

My herds provided me with plenty of milk,
\q2 and streams of oil flowed from the rock where my servants pressed the olives.
\b
\q1

Whenever I went to the place where the elders gathered at the city gate,
\q2 I sat down with them,
\q1

and when the young men saw me, they stepped aside respectfully,
\q2 and the old men also stood respectfully.
\q1

The leaders of the people used to stop talking,
\q1

and even the most important men became quiet
\q2 and stopped talking in order to hear me speak to them.
\q1

When they all heard what I told them,
\q2 they said good things about me.
\q1 When they saw me, they always praised me
\q1

because I had helped the poor people when they cried out for help,
\q2 and because I aided orphans who had no one else to help them.
\q1

Those who were suffering and about to die praised me,
\q2 and I caused widows to sing joyfully, because I helped them.
\q1

It was as though I myself saw for blind people
\q2 and walked for people who were lame.
\q1

I was like a father to the poor people,
\q2 and in the courts I defended those who were strangers to me.
\q1

I made wicked people stop oppressing others; it was like someone who breaks the teeth of wild animals
\q2 and forces them to drop their victims from their teeth.
\b
\q1

At that time I thought, 'Surely I will live in peace until I am very old,
\q2 and I will die at home with my family.'
\q1

I was like a tree whose roots reach down into the water
\q2 and whose branches become wet with dew each night.
\q1

People always honored me,
\q2 and I was always strong like a new bow.
\b
\q1

"But now, men who are younger than I am make fun of meâ€”
\q2 men whose fathers I greatly despisedâ€”
\q2 their fathers, whom I would not even have allowed to help my dogs guard my sheep.
\q1

They were very poor and hungry,
\q2 so that they chewed on roots at night
\q2 in dry and desolate places.
\q1

Everyone shouted at them, "Stop, thief!"
\q2 and drove them from their area.
\q1

They were forced to live in riverbeds,
\q2 in holes in the ground, and in the sides of cliffs.
\q1

In the bushes they howled like animals because they were hungry,
\q2 and they huddled together under thornbushes.
\q1

They were people without good sense,
\q2 whose names no one knows;
\q1 they were driven out from the land where they were born.
\q1

Now their children sing songs to make fun of me.
\q2 They tell jokes about me.
\q1

They are disgusted with me, and they stay away from me,
\q2 but when they see me, they are happy to spit in my face.
\q1

It seems as though God had cut my bowstring and caused me to be unable to defend myself; he has humbled me,
\q2 and my enemies have done to me whatever they wanted.
\q1

They prevent me from escaping,
\q2 and there is no one to keep them from attacking me.
\q1

It is as though I were a city wall and they had broken through it,

\q1

I am very terrified;
\q2 my dignity has been blown away by the wind,

\q1

My bones ache during the nights,

\q1

It is as though God had grabbed my clothes
\q2 and choked me by the collar of my coat.
\q1

He has thrown me into the mud;
\q2 I am not worth anything more than dust and ashes.
\b
\q1

I know that you will cause me to die,
\q2 which is what happens to everyone who is alive.
\b
\q1

When people experience disasters,
\q2 they sit on a pile of ruins and cry out for help;
\q2 they certainly cry out for help.
\q1

I myself wept for people who were experiencing troubles,
\q2 and I felt sorry for poor people.
\q1

My wailing is as sad as jackals and ostriches in the wilderness.
\q1

My skin has become dark and is peeling off,
\q2 and I have a fever which causes my body to feel as though it were burning up with a fever.
\q1

Previously, I played joyful music on my harp and with my flute,
\q2 but now I play only the sad music of those who mourn."

"I made to myself a solemn promise

If I did not do what I promised,

After Yahweh said these things to Job, he said to Eliphaz, "I am angry with you and your two friends, Bildad and Zophar, because you did not say true things about me, as my servant Job did.

So now you must take to Job seven young bulls and seven rams and kill them and burn them on the altar as a sacrifice for yourselves. Then Job will pray for you, and I will do what he requests me to do. I will forgive you for speaking wrongly about me. I will not punish you, even though you deserve to be punished, because what you said about me was not right."
So Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar did what Yahweh commanded them to do, and Yahweh did what Job requested him to do for the three of them.
After Job prayed for his three friends, Yahweh healed him and caused him to become rich again. Yahweh gave him twice as many things as he had before.

Then all his brothers and sisters, and all the people who had known him before, came to his house, and they had a feast together. They consoled him because of all the troubles that Yahweh had allowed to happen to him. Each of them gave Job a piece of silver and a gold ring.

Then Yahweh blessed Job in the second half of his life more than he had blessed him in the first half of his life. He now acquired fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.
And he also had seven more sons and three more daughters.
He named the first daughter Jemimah, he named the second daughter Keziah, and he named the third daughter Keren Happuch.

In all of the land of Uz, there were no young women who were as beautiful as the daughters of Job, and Job declared that they would inherit some of his possessions, just as their brothers would inherit some.
After that, Job lived 140 more years. Before he died, he saw his great-great-grandchildren.
He was very old when he died.
